chargeHist.descr: Homicide by Intoxicated Use of Vehicle
Homicide by Use of Vehicle with PAC

result.execSummary:
The defendant Heather D. Schmidt was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Heather D. Schmidt is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Heather D. Schmidt was found guilty of Homicide by Intoxicated Use of Vehicle, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.09(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Defendant granted huber privileges, except for the last 5 weeks of sentence.

Defendant shall not possess or consume any alcoholic beverages.  Absolute sobriety.
Defendant shall not possess any illegal substances.
Defendant shall not possess any drug paraphernalia as defined in Chapter 961.
Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on a highway in this state unless authorized by MVD.

Defendant to pay supervision fees as determined by DOC.
Provide biological specimen to State Crime Lab for DNA analysis.
Defendant shall take prescription medication in the manner and method as prescribed.
Defendant shall obtain all prescriptions for one (1) pharmacy and report new or changes of prescriptions to Agent within 48 hours.
Defendant shall attend, two (2) times annually, public education regarding OWI.
Defendant shall operate vehicles only equipped with IID during probation.
Defendant shall attend the Victim Offender Impact Panel.

timeConds.notes: The last 5 weeks of the sentence are to be served on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, February 10 and July 19 without huber privileges on those days.
